awd_titl_txt: RUI: Quantum Sensing and Simulation with Ultracold Atoms in Ring Lattices
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum technologies will play a central role in shaping human and societal progress in this century, as devices and applications reach limits set by classical physics, and are inevitably impelled into the realms of quantum mechanics to sustain continued advancement. Owing to fundamentally different principles and constraints involved, such migration will be selective rather than comprehensive, and the arenas of sensing, simulation and computation are the most promising.  This project focuses on the first two aspects as they can already deliver considerable benefits even in the near term. Quantum effects have been demonstrated to offer substantial enhancement of sensitivity to accelerations, while due to the enormous dimensions of relevant Hilbert spaces, quantum systems are the best simulators of quantum physics with a designer system serving to mimic hard-to-access scenarios of interest. Underlying all such goals, however, the defining challenge continues to be the fragility of quantum states and effects as they interface with the classical world. Therefore, broad success hinges on finding the right platform. This project aims to study and develop a novel alternate platform comprised of ultracold atoms confined to a ring-shaped periodic lattice, a system that is robust, yet encompasses all quantum-mechanical features relevant for applications.  The closed loop structure makes for a compact unit that mitigates boundary effects, favors sustained flow, allows easy scaling of size and multiplicity, and directly manifests the quintessential quantum feature of non-locality. The variable lattice structure provides a versatile way to manipulate the system while providing a precise scale for relevant observables. Training of numerous undergraduate students in physics research will be a priority, building on success under prior grants to leverage the experience to channel students into STEM career paths, including many from under-represented demographics.   

The goals for sensor development comprise two primary directions. One is based on a new principle that utilizes a localization transition that occurs in ring-shaped lattices. In the context of neutral atoms, the principle can be adapted for rotation detection and measurement. Alternately, with a charged medium, it can be similarly adapted for sensing magnetic fields. The second line of research will seek to generate squeezed states of circulating modes in ring lattices to realize implementations of interferometers that use quantum correlated states to improve sensitivity, as exemplified by SU(1,1) interferometers.  As a quantum simulator, the system will be utilized to explore the physics of superfluidity and associated transitions to insulator states, as well as the impact of topology on quantum states, such as defined by the quantum Hall effect. With the lattice coupling the circulating modes in a ring much like a laser field couples electronic states in an atom, the system will also be developed as a quantum-optics simulator.  With natural periodic boundaries mitigating some finite size effects, cold atoms in ring lattices can be a new platform for studying non-equilibrium physics, including questions of thermalization and relaxation of many-body quantum systems. Interplay of inter-atomic interactions and of the lattice structure in a ring configuration will allow simulation of various nonlinear dynamical effects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Successful deployment of quantum technologies for real world applications strongly hinges on the specific qualities of available platforms, because of the fragile nature of the essential quantum features of coherence and entanglement.  Ultracold atoms confined by a ring-shaped trap with an azimuthal lattice structure, present a robust platform that meets all desired criteria. While certain aspects are readily apparent, such as the coherence of the medium and that the ring structure constitutes a naturally closed unit, this research has demonstrated that the ring lattice system also present other quantum features necessary to make the system a universally viable platform.

It was shown that a high degree of entanglement can be generated in the ring system, by using two species of mutually interacting ultracold atoms.  The system can accommodate a large number of atoms in a ring, and the coherence and entanglement are manifest in the collective spin states of the system as a whole. This therefore can operate as a macroscopic platform, as opposed to microscopic ones that rely on the behavior of individual atoms. Apart from making it a more robust system, the larger degrees of freedom available allows alternate implementation of quantum protocols, such as continuous variable quantum computation.

Interatomic interactions are inherently present among ultracold atoms, and lead to effective nonlinear behavior, and this project conducted a thorough study of the collective quantum states in a ring-shaped lattice for both repulsive and attractive interactions. Such understanding is essential for any future application of this platform. Additionally, this also paves the way for simulation of nonlinear dynamics in these systems. A comprehensive landscape of nonlinear scattering solutions in effective one dimension, also determined in this research will further facilitate that.

The ring lattice system was demonstrated as a comprehensive simulator for quantum optical phenomena, with the medium and the lattice standing in for electronic states within atoms coupled to a light field. Furthermore, by broadening the ring lattice to cylindrical and toroidal configurations, and introducing an effective gauge field, numerous features emerge that are intrinsically tied to the non-trivial topology of such setups. Particularly, using small lattices feasible in the context of ultracold atoms, the system allows simulation of the intricate interplay of topology and quantum mechanics.

Most of the phenomena manifest with quantum states in ring configurations are sensitive to rotation, and it was shown that such sensitivity can be harnessed in multiple ways to create high precision rotation sensors. A United States patent was awarded for work associated with this research, which presented a novel mechanism for high precision rotation sensing based on a localization principle rather than the traditional use of interferometry. The patent also recognized the utility of the mechanism for sensing magnetic fields for the case of a charged medium.  A continuation patent was filed and is pending, wherein protocols for calibration and measurement were presented for such sensors.

Broader Impact

Ultracold atoms in a ring lattice system, along with extensions to analogous two-dimensional configurations like cylinder or torus, has been shown to be a versatile simulator for quantum optics and nonlinear physics in addition to serving as a robust platform for emerging quantum technologies. The sensor capabilities extend from gyroscopy to high-precision magnetometry as recognized by a US patent award.

This project trained about a dozen undergraduate students in research, with most of them coauthoring one or more peer-reviewed scientific papers. Notably, one of the female student participants was awarded the LeRoy Apker award of the American Physical Society, the highest recognition for undergraduate research in the United States, with only two recipients each year from across the nation. This along with the excellent placement of several students in some of the best doctoral programs in physics underscore the high quality of training provided within the aegis of this project. Several of the student participants were women and from other demographic groups underrepresented in physics. Additionally, several graduate students from multiple universities were also trained as participants in this research, and almost all of them are on track to be coauthors on resulting publications.
